text:
Schermerhorn Street, north side, between Third (left) and Flatbush Aves.(right), showing the sinking of the Catskill Water Shaft on the site of the former Ritters Painless Dental Company building, now known as Temple Square.

1917.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

Schermerhorn Street, north side, between Third and Flatbush Aves. In the background, is Flatbush Ave., and the Fulton Street Line of the B.M.T. This site is now known as "Temple Square".

About 1920.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

Schermerhorn Street, south side, between Flatbush and Third Avenues, showing the building of the Young Women's Christian Association, the view being across Temple Square. The building was later put up for sale by the Charles F. Noyes Company.

About 1925

P. L. Sperr

38-54 Lafayette Street, south side, west from Navy Street. In the background, is seen the Fulton Elevated Line of The B.M.T.

October 31, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

Flatbush Avenue Extension, east side, from Lafayette Street(left) to Debevoise Place, showing several old rookeries and gasoline stations. On the extreme right is a portion of the Paramount Theatre Building; the 4-story house on the left is on Lafayette Street and Debevoise Place.

April 7, 1932

P. L. Sperr

(2)

The same location, at a later date. The two upper stories of the Zappa Brothers gas station were removed; the other rookeries remaining intact, except for the change of tenants.

April 27, 1940

P. L. Sperr

(3)

The same block, viewing from Debevoise Place to Lafayette Street. Debevoise Place is on the extreme right and forms a forty-five degree angle with Flatbush Avenue. Beyond the Paramount Bowling Center is the four-story tenement seen on the left in view. Shown, too, is the factory of the Edison Screw Machine Products Company, also known as the Maltz Building.

April 27, 1940

P. L. Sperr

Neg* 1237

Neg* 1237

Lafayette Street, east from Navy Street. Also seen in the foreground, is 219 Navy Street, at the N.E. corner of Lafayette Street. In the background, is Ashland Place, east side, showing part of the City Prison, commonly known as Raymond Street Jail.

July 10, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

Flatbush Avenue Extension, east side, between Lafayette Street and Debevoise Place, showing a triangular plot occupied by a gasoline station and a few old rookeries. On the right is the Paramount Theatre building. On the left is an old tenement at the southeast corner of Lafayette and Debevoise, also shown in view 2.

P. L. Sperr

August 23, 1939
Views 1,2

Flatbush Avenue Extension, east side, between Lafayette Street and Debevoise Place, showing a triangular plot occupied by a gasoline station and a few old rookeries. On the right is the Paramount Theatre building. On the left is an old tenement at the southeast corner of Lafayette and Debevoise, also shown in view 2.

P. L. Sperr

August 23, 1939
Views 1,2

A general view westward from No. 1 Hanson Place, the Williamsburg Savings Bank Building, toward the East River and the Lower Manhattan skyline (view 2). The two prominent thoroughfares running from the fore- to the background are: Schermerhorn Street (right), with the Baptist Temple at the corner of Third Avenue, and State Street. The modern building, in the left foreground, is the Y. W. C. A.; another Y. W. C. A. is the quadrangular building in the center of the view, extending from State to Schermerhorn Streets, at Neving Street. In the center background is the Abraham and Straus department store. In the upper right-hand corner (view 1) are the Montague-Court and the Court-Remsen Buildings.

May 12, 1939
Views 1,2

P. L. Sperr
title: General view - Brooklyn.

text:
A general view westward from No. 1 Hanson Place, the Williamsburg Savings Bank Building, toward the East River and the Lower Manhattan skyline (view 2). The two prominent thoroughfares running from the fore- to the background are: Schermerhorn Street (right), with the Baptist Temple at the corner of Third Avenue, and State Street. The modern building, in the left foreground, is the Y. W. C. A.; another Y. W. C. A. is the quadrangular building in the center of the view, extending from State to Schermerhorn Streets, at Neving Street. In the center background is the Abraham and Straus department store. In the upper right-hand corner (view 1) are the Montague-Court and the Court-Remsen Buildings.

May 12, 1939
Views 1,2

P. L. Sperr
